comment.author: 31536722@N00
comment._content:
So long ago. How things have changed in just over a hundred years. Photography no longer feels like a 'new' technology. It's been around for a good while now. 

Keep putting up these wonderful images.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Fabulous picture. I wonder what was meant by 'quite a modern institution,' as Slater's Commercial Directory noted many hotels which were post houses as well forty six years earlier, in 1846. Perhaps the mail car to that part of Galway was modern, whereas mail from Galway to other parts would be commonplace. Slater made a point of noting the exact time mail cars for specific towns left the post houses. But the picture is excellent, just wondering what the photographer was referring to.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mosskayree] Good point! I've assumed it was the car going to this location that was the innovation but the chances of identifying this location are infuriatingly slim... See, the back story is that this photo was taken for James Hack Tuke, a Quaker philanthropist who was really interested in advancing the economic development of Ireland.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
